messages: 73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (14:52): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, role is for stylable form controls? I thought it was more than that.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:53): role is magical
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:53): Somehow everyone will know and agree on which roles mean what, and never use them incorrectly or make up their own roles
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (14:55): what code will access the role attribute?
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (14:55): I mean, CSS could, with [role=foo], but I'm assuming that's undesirable.
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (14:56): screen readers?
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (14:57): search engines?
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (14:59): automatic text summarisers?
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (14:59): throw me a bone here, people :/
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:59): The people talking most about it are the accessability people, so screen readers
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:00): <i role="shipname">Titanic</i> for example?
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:01): how is role supposed to connect to RDF, anyway?
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:01): I mean how does it differ from class?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:01): See my initial statement
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:03): hmm, from what I see on the mailing list, people want to say role="foo:shipname"
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:03): where foo is a currently bound namespace prefix
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:03): -1 for qnames in content...
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:04): i don't see the point in linking to RDF
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:04): how exactly will user agents "learn" about new roles
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:04): is it really intended that UAs will read the RDF and then magically know what to do with the role?
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:04): that was the kind of insane magic thinking that came out when XML Namespaces where designed
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:05): "a namespace is a URL, user agent dereferences URL, downloads schema for namespace (why?), magically knows what to do"
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:05): was it?
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:06): RDDL was a language designed for that very purpose
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:06): to add namespace metadata to an XHTML page that sits on the namespace URL
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:06): sighs
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:06): so that hypothetical user agents could go and download it and learn new tricks
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:07): I don't know how many smart people burnt processor cycles on that idea
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:07): the fact that most user agents don't even bother downloading DTDs should have been a hint
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:07): (Prince does, actually :)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:07): does it learn new tricks from DTDs? :)
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:08): but wouldn't it be awesome if you could just define new elements in the DTD,
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:08): and they got all kinds of custom rendering behaviour automatically,
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:08): and we didn't have to do any work! That'd rock.
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:10): I mean, the only thing you can do in RDF that doesn't involve writing code,
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:10): is tell the user agent that a foreign element is equivalent to some other known element
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:10): like, if you see a <foo>, treat it just like you currently treat <blockquote>
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:11): now that might be handy, from time to time, but it's hardly a world changing feature.

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:11): i meant with my first remark that it appears that that was what spawned the role idea in the first place. then they thought "hey, this can be useful for other stuff too!" or something
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:11): and made it even more complicated
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:11): so it was originally proposed for styling form controls?
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:11): seems like improved CSS selectors would solve that one
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:12): dunno, just speculating. i don't understand the problem it's trying to solve really
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:12): indeed
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:12): or selectors are already powerful enough
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:12): role was from XHTML 2 originally though, right?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:12): probably. does it make a difference?
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:13): just trying to find out where it all began
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:13): looks like it was an XHTML module:
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:13): that came afterwards
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:13): as an attempt to "ease migration to xhtml2" (or so the draft says)
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:13): It is used by applications and assistive technologies to determine the purpose of UI widgets.
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:13): (UI widgets sentence should be in quotes)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:14): yeah
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:14): thing is there already is HTML markup for UI widgets!
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:14): <button>, <a href>, <input type=checkbox>
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:14): the example has it on a list: <ul role="navigation wai:sitemap">
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:14): <nav>
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:15): <nav><h2>Sitemap</h2><ul>...
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:15): to be honest, some of these role values remind me of rel=""
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:16): I can sort of see what they're trying to do with it, and it's not *too* insane
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:16): but the idea of qnames in attributes, and linking it to RDF via namespace URLs is just stupid
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:16): role seems to be like an accessibility patch for poor CSS support in browsers and badly written markup
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:16): the whole point is to have a small selection of values that user agents understand
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:16): which might be a good thing
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:16): some of it could also be handy for mobile rendering,
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:17): like when you want to chop the page up into bits to fit on a small screen
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:17): you want to know where to chop, and role could help with that
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:17): i mean, if there is old content with <img onclick>, it's easier to add role=checkbox than to change it to <input type=checkbox> and restyle it
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:17): but again, define a small number of roles, make sure user agents understand them, ditch the namespace stuff
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:17): yeah
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:17): people might go nuts inventing new role values, but that's fine
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:18): since it's not useful for styling, only accessibility nuts will go nuts, which is okay
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:19): hmm, just like the rel attribute, actually
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:19): rel="shortcut icon"
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:19): and the hook for OpenID
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:20): rel="openid.server", works fine with no namespace support
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:20): it's just that every W3C specification has to pay homage to RDF at some point...
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:21): indeed, i don't see why namespaces are better than naming conventions
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:22): naming conventions seem to be more successful in terms of usage and implementation
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:22): microformats are naming conventions
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:23): some implementations of RSS rely on the convention of how the namespace prefixes are written!
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:23): (i think)
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:25): pseudo-XML formats, not really XML
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:25): but namespaces should never have been defined using URLs to begin with
73c8ec97fe210f482d81a5f04e5e6642 (15:25): http://www.xml.com/pub/a/2005/04/13/namespace-uris.html
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:31): have a predefined set of prefixes, and if you don't want to use a prefix, then you have to declare the namespace
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:31): <html:html/> == <html xmlns="html"/>
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:31): that could have worked
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:32): unknown prefixes are just that, handled the same way as unknown namespaces are today
